reviews.review_title: "Dragon Wars" is no "Reign of Fire"
reviews.content: Cheesy computer generated special effects, campy storytelling, and constipated performances make writer & director Hyung Rae Shim's ambitious new monster movie "Dragon Wars" look and sound hilariously awful. Indeed, "Dragon Wars" is so bad that it qualifies as good, but good in the sense that it stinks like Limburger cheese! You'll find yourself cackling out loud at the reverence with which Shim treats his outrageously ridiculous material. Just as outrageous in another sense is the money that he squandered on this indulgent opus. Reports have varied in the media about the budget of this half-baked South Korean cinematic epic since it premiered earlier this year in Berlin. Initially, publicists said "Dragon Wars" cost a whopping $70 million. The latest figures put this monstrous mythological creature feature more realistically at $30 million. Typically, this kind of incoherent juvenile gibberish heads directly to the shelves of your local video rental store before it takes up permanent residence on the Sci-Fi Channel alongside similar schlock like "Boa," "Python," or "Komodo Vs. Cobra." Incredibly, Freestyle Releasing audaciously distributed prints of this dreadful dragon drivel to 2,275 theaters! Comparatively, the new Billy Bob Thornton comedy "Mr. Woodcock" illuminated only 2, 231 screens. Clearly, Freestyle and Shim are gambling that they can mop up millions from moviegoers that need either something idiotic to laugh at or parents who can't find anything better for their children to see.The action opens in Los Angeles as CGNN-TV reporter Ethan Kendrick (Tom Cruise look-alike Jason Behr of "The Grudge") covers a disaster at the Seven Palms Resort. FBI agents Frank Pinsky (Chris Mulkey of "Heartbreak Hotel") and Judah Campbell (John Ales of "Spy Hard") send Ethan packing when he quizzes them about the catastrophe. Before Ethan leaves, he tapes footage with his camcorder of a Fed dusting off a suspicious looking fossil in the rubble. The sight of the specimen rekindles memories of fifteen years earlier when our hero saw something similar in an antiques shop. An ancient Asian crate burst its locks of its own accord, like a Pandora's Box, and bathed young Ethan (Cody Arens of "Shadow Man") in a blaze of light. The antiques dealer, Jack (Robert Forester of "Firewall"), tells Ethan a loquacious story about legendary good and evil giant Korean serpents called 'Imoogi' that battle for supremacy over the Earth and Heaven. Shim treats us to a flashback within a flashback during Jack's story. According to Jack, a Korean girl found herself impregnated about 500 years ago with a mystical source of power called the Yuh Yi Joo. When the girl reached age twenty, she was supposed to impart this Yuh Yi Joo to the good 'Imoogi' serpent. As it turns out, Jack was a martial arts master back then in his previous life and Ethan served as his warrior sidekick. Flashbacks of gravity-defying kung fu warriors battling black-clad armies of swordsmen with chrome helmets pad out Jack's yarn. Everything here resembles those goofy action sequences straight out of Kung Fu Theater. Jack and Ethan were responsible for safeguarding the girl until she could pass along the Yuh Yi Joo to the virtuous Imoogi. Something went wrong, and the Imoogi as well as our heroes and heroine have had to wait another 500 years to complete the process.Back in modern day L.A., Ethan learns from Jack that a 19-year old girl, Sarah (Amanda Brooks of "Flightplan"), has the Yuh Yi Joo growing inside of her. Jack and he must protect her from the evil Imoogi's army, the Buraki, that are searching relentlessly for her. Meanwhile, the bad Imoogibasically a gargantuan anaconda with a head like a "Jurassic Park" T-Rex dinosaurslithers all over the architecture of L.A. searching for Sarah. The Buraki also dispatch flocks of flying dinos that scour the city for Sarah. The U.S. military responds to this threat with attack helicopter gunships. Basically, "Dragon Wars" tries to imitate on a considerably smaller scale the wholesale destruction of L.A. that occurred in "Transformers." Before he turned director, Hyung Rae Shim was a well-known Korean television comedian. Despite the grave reverence that he holds for his native land's legends about combative dragons, Shim cannot translate that conviction to the big-screen. "Dragon Wars" is a hootenanny from start to finish. The giant serpent is the equivalent of Wiley E. Coyote and our heroes and heroine are Roadrunners. The American actors cast in the contemporary scenes struggle with dialogue that is so lame and convoluted that it's a tribute to their thespian talents that they can keep a straight face. Some scenes, especially those involving a zookeeper, are downright sidesplitting. The CGI special effects of the Imoogi fall light years short of the standard Hollywood technology. Mind you, these quirky dragons have their moments, particularly in the destruction of Los Angeles. Just when you want to give this nonsense the benefit of the doubt, the good dragon sprouts reindeer antlers and catfish whiskers and triumphs over the evil dragon. "Dragon Wars" makes the recent Japanese "Godzilla" extravaganzas look like Shakespearian material. Clearly, "Dragon Wars" is no "Reign of Fire."

reviews.review_title: a non-recommendation caveat
reviews.content: Did I see this? Sure, about eight years ago when it came out on DVD of course! Do I remember much from it? Absolutelyf**king not! reviews.review_title: A bad film with some fun moments.
reviews.content: D-War is set in modern day Los Angeles where television news reporter Ethan Kendrick (Jason Behr) sudden remembers the ancient Korean tale of powerful Serpent's named Imoogi that get to transform into even more powerful Dragon's & go to heaven if they eat a glowing orb which is found inside a newborn baby every 500 years, there are good Imoogi & bad Imoogi. Ethan feels the time is almost upon the world again & a 19 year old girl named Sarah (Amanda Brooks) holds the orb & that with her twentieth birthday approaching an evil Imoogi named Buraki & it's army of followers are after her to get the orb & turn Baraki into a powerful Dragon & wreck destruction on the world. Ethan feels it's his destiny to find Sarah & protect her from Buraki & save the world from the Dragon wars...Also commonly known as Dragon Wars this South Korean production was written & directed by Hyung-rae Shim & is admittedly ambitious & not without it's fun moments but to be honest D-War is a mess of film that tries to blind you with special effects & extravagant set-pieces but is hollow, unsatisfying & makes no sense. The script is as sloppy as any I've seen in a while, the whole back-story with the ancient Korean legend lost me almost straight away with it's over complicated rules & KJorean names for people & things that I then find hard to associate with anything. The Eastern mysticism & ancient wars & Dragons & orbs & stuff just went over my head & it's hard to make any sense of it to the extent by the time the film was nearing it's end I wasn't sure what was happening, why it was happening or what significance it would have. There are gaping holes in the narrative, how does the evil Imoogi control it's army? Where was the good Imoogi when Los Angeles was being destroyed& why couldn't it have come to the rescue earlier (like 500 years earlier)? Who is that evil Imoogi general guy? Do we really need a flashback within a flashback? Where did that army come from? Where have they been for the last 500 years? Why hasn't the good Imoogi got an army? How can a giant snake slither all over Los Angeles & people not notice or keep track of it? Where does the end of the film take place? How is Ethan meant to get back home? Why couldn't that pendant thing just destroy Buraki's army to start with? If the evil army & those flying creatures want Sarah alive why do they seemingly keep trying to kill her by spitting fireballs at her car? There are some many questions unanswered, so much narrative that seems missing that it's impossible take take anything meaningful away from D-War. Also, what are moments of humour all about? An old woman walking into a fence, that evil warlord guy getting run over & that security guard at the zoo just feel so out of place.The one aspect where D-War sometimes succeeds is it's set-pieces & special effects, the final half of the film is none stop monster mayhem as the forces of the evil Imoogi battle it out against the military might of the US in Los Angeles which is great fun. From slow lumbering monsters walking through the streets taking on tanks to flying creatures that fight helicopter to the huge Imoogi who gets to trash a car park & wrap itself around a skyscraper while causing all sorts of destructive havoc. The special effects & CGI computer graphics look alright actually, while I didn't watch this in Hi-Def on Blu-ray so I can't comment on how the effects stand up in that regard they looked alright when the DVD version is watched. The set-pieces have a certain imagination & charm, they are certainly memorable & if watching giant monsters trash Los Angeles appeals to you then you could do worse than D-War. Being a family friendly PG rated film there's no excessive gore or violence although there are a few tame martial arts battles at the start.With a supposed budget of about $70,000,000 this apparently took fives years to complete & was the first Korean film in over thirty years to receive a wide theatrical release in the states where, it has to be said, it didn't particularly impress. The acting is really bad, it's full of bland & bad performances especially Jason Behr who is a terrible leading men here.D-War is a terrible fantasy film that rips off much better fantasy films & is just one big mess but it has some undeniably cool set-pieces & effects even though they did start to blur into one another by the end. Watchable in a bad Power Rangers sort of way I suppose or if your under seven years old but even then you will find the story parts boring & confusing.

reviews.review_title: An ambitious movie that really falls kind of flat...
reviews.content: You can tell whoever made this wanted something big, something on the scale of a Lord of the Rings type film, but with some modern settings; however, it fails. This is probably due to a lack of budget as most of the effects are none too good as the dinosaurs from the 1993 Jurassic Park look more alive. Then again, as fake as the dragons look, they feel more real than the actors performances in this thing. I also get the feeling the makers just wanted to get to the rampaging as there are just so many characters relegated to seemingly important plot points but with no backstory! They just appear and do stuff to advance the plot and vanish like the wind!The story, two dragons need to eat one particular girl to become more powerful! One is evil and one is good. A news reporter sees something that triggers a flashback that triggers another flashback and we learn of the tragic and stupid tale. The reporter who is played by a guy that was probably voted most bland man of the year in 2007 then must find the girl who makes Kristen Stewart during her Twilight run look Oscar worthy and he must grab her by the arm and pull her as a big snake like dragon comes after them! We then get an attack on L. A. before going to the set of Mortal Kombat II for the finish!The effects at time look okay, but even when it looks like all this awesome stuff is happening and there is devastation the buildings look absolutely fine underneath. It is like you see debris flying everywhere, but no actual damage. The acting is beyond subpar and as I said, so many characters popping up with virtually no story, like the doctor and the hypnosis which accomplished nothing.The movie had some entertaining moments within it, too bad they could not do a bit better with the technical stuff and get better actors. I am unclear why they chose to film this in L. A. rather than somewhere in Korea, it would have been nice if the lead guy was not so useless as his former self was way more cool.

reviews.review_title: Terrible...
reviews.content: This film made absolutely no sense. There's so many implausible events that it's hilarious how they try to pass it off to continue with the "story". This old mentor guy manages to tell an 8-year-old kid a story that takes 20-minutes to tell... and it's not even an enthralling tale, and how an 8-year-old managed to hold his attention span that long is beyond me. The acting is atrocious, be it the lead actors or the secondary characters. Continuity is full of unconnected dots and zig-zags. The screenplay is the worst of the year. This is a very confusing film, and the quickness the male and female lead fall in love is completely ridiculous. The only good thing would have to be the special effects, and even those can get REALLY old REALLY fast. The sweeping camera shots are not epic, they're the biggest cheese next to the nonsensical plot -- the ending made no sense at all... NONE. The dialogue is all over the place -- I highly doubt there are data banks that have a person detailed so well, you can type in "dragon tattoo" and it will give the name and address of said person. Malarkey through and through, do NOT see D-War.

reviews.review_title: Jurassic Park + King Kong + lobotomy = DULL WARS
reviews.content: I, like the previous reviewer, also attended the preview/premiere in Seoul. I was very glad that I didn't pay for the tickets.Admittedly, I am not part of the target audience (12 - 14 years old, mentally or physically) but there was nothing there for anyone older.It's so easy to criticize this movie, I'll keep it brief.a 1st draft script: you can check-off the clichés as you hear them - "this is gonna sound crazy but...". CHIII-YEK! Authority figure turns around just in time to NOT see the beast CHIII-YEK!it takes itself way, waaaay too seriously: come on fellas, its a film about dragons, soften those frowns a little.Zero chemistry between the leads: maybe they were all CG? Here are the good things: the Korean version I saw is shorter than the European one - sorry, my European friends, you have 17 more excruciating minutes.In conclusion, if you like CG, buy a PS3 or a Wii. If you want to be entertained, D-War is not the place.

reviews.review_title: Not bad enough to be funny
reviews.content: This is the sorriest collection of clichés, strung together on a straight line, with no discernible plot or any decent way of acting I've seen in a long time. Canibalising scenes from Star Wars, Reign of Fire, Godzilla, Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter, it went for an all out war on the viewer intelligence. Was this movie good? It wasn't a movie at all!Even if it doesn't go so low to actually be funny and achieve cult status as a comedy, the movie does offer some laughs. The trick is to put the copied scenes in the context of their original films. Gandalf can be funny talking Korean, the basilisk looking snake hilarious if you compare it to a kitten and the evil henchman can provide a lot of fun switching back and forth between Sauron and Jaja-bing, or whatever his name was.Bottom line: any pleasure derived from this movie is completely dependent on the state of intoxication and imagination of the viewers, not on the director/writer. Shame on you, Shim!

reviews.content: I have never seen such a movie before. I was on the edge of my seat and constantly laughing throughout the entire movie. I never thought such horrible acting existed it was all just too funny. The story behind the movie is decent but the movies scenes fail to portray them. I have never seen such a stupid movie in my life which is why it I think its worth watching. I give this movie 10 out of 10 for being the most pathetic movie ever created, this movie seems like it was solely created to become trash. I mean the scenes seem so fake and the actors act like "the camera is in front of them". You will get a kick just watching how lame this movie is, me and my friend could not stop making jokes during the movie, the darthvader guy who tries to get the girl got ran over not once but twice and the second time he got ran over it sounded like he said sh!# although he doesn't speak English lol. If you watch this movie you will think to yourself that all those other movies you didn't like you took for granted they are way better than this. This movie should be seen out of curiosity as well as what kind of movie DEFINES lame. The evil serpent encountered the girl so many times it was ridiculous, the evil serpent just roared and roared and let her get away every time. The evil serpent had so many chances it was like god was trying to say hurry up and eat the girl how many miracles do you want. The transition between scenes leaves you wondering did I miss something? So many plot holes from scene to scene. I was laughing like crazy when they decided to "Escape To Mexico" to get away from the serpent. Hmmmm hopping the border will save you from a serpent from Korea? interesting... very interesting.... I guess hopping the border solves all problems. Another scene that completely stupified me.. they met for the first time and had a romantic scene at the beach they kissed and didn't even know each other... the scene was so clichéd and the was no substance at least in other movies it might seem logical afterwhile but i mean they JUST MET even though they are reincarnations there feelings were like they instantly loved each other instead of it rather developing. Anyways this movie is worth watching for the sake of opening your eyes and seeing the light. Bad Hollywood movies will seem like heaven when compared to this. In the end its worth watching you wont get bored you will be occupied criticizing every moment, every scene in your head.

reviews.review_title: Great Effects ....at least
reviews.content: Okay ,the movie was badly made.in fact quiet badly made. Characters were motionless and emotionless and whatever...but the SFX were very Good. In fact I can compare these effects with the likes of robocops and star wars(the ground fights at least). The apache versus 1000 foot snake and apache versus gargoyles in the crowded building laced streets of LA was pretty coolly done.so basically the whole movie is only the last 15-20 minutes, that's the money's worth and the length before that is well like everyone said, hogwash.Good CGI, something at least I saw after some long time. In fact I can compare these effects with the likes of robocops and star wars(the ground fights at least). The apache versus 1000 foot snake and apache versus gargoyles in the crowded building laced streets of LA was pretty coolly done.so basically the whole movie is only the last 15-20 minutes, that's the money's worth and the length before that is well like everyone said, hogwash.Good CGI, something at least I saw after some long time.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as you were led to believe.
reviews.content: Dragon Wars(D-Wars)has almost everything that science-fiction fans should want:a good cast,a decent plot,and excellent special effects that defines this movie for what it really is.I must admit that D-Wars isn't one of the best action films I've ever seen,but it did keep me interested long enough until the end credits came.Basically the movie is about a reporter who finds out that an ancient war between humans and dragons will rage upon the world.I know it sounds pretty lame,but the movie is actually pretty good.I'm glad that this movie didn't win any Razzies because I probably would've been a little confused that many people call this movie an abomination.Well,it's not.Enjoy it for what it is.

reviews.review_title: Korean Style special effects collides with Hollycrap target marketing of an audience with no brain cells.
reviews.content: This movie starts out very promising but quickly disintegrates into garbage special effects, crap editing and wooden acting. Politically Correct Americans will cringe as they are faced with a variety of kitsch stereotype characters that are borrowed from other American films. The Korean pandering to what it perceives as the American audience is heavy handed and super obvious and detracts from what makes foreign films interesting- the foreignness. The director works very hard to try and compete in an American fluff action film market and in doing so gives up style, creativity and imagination. The action sequences look like they were lifted directly from Jurassic park or star wars and are unrealistic at best, cartoonish at worst.Make no mistake- this is a VERY FUN B movie if you understand that this is a stupid B movie- it is gloriously cheesy including a dark army horde headed up by a Darth Vader style villain complete with an organic version of the Empire Strikes Back's famous battle scene on Hoth, only this time it is in Korea using dragons. There are lots of OH NO GODZILLA scenes as well.If you remove all expectations from the actors to act, and instead expect the movie to play out like a crappy comic book- then you will enjoy this. IF you wanted to see a movie about dragons that is cool and exciting- skip this movie. It seems to be a law in film making that every dragon movie and every vampire movie has to suck. A small handful of films have escaped this MacBeth-like curse. That's sad since those themes are the two most popular themes in legend you would think someone would take the time to treat sacred legends as sacred instead of a schlock filler for their lack of imagination in creating a script.SIDE NOTE: Americans that ignorantly bought into the terrorism fear campaign orchestrated by our unelected dictator-in-chief Herr Bush may cringe at various scenes of aircraft flying into New York buildings- it may remind you of the twin towers too much.

reviews.review_title: Fun, like Star Wars Ep 1-3 without the hype and JarJar
reviews.content: There something about tanks shooting at monsters destroying a city that brings out the little kid in me. Reminds of Ultraman and Godzilla on Saturday mornings, only this time, it's not done with cheap models and men in rubber suits. I found the special effects to surprisingly good and believable. A cross between Spiderman, King Kong, LOTR and Star Wars - if you see it you'll understand. Also lots of cheap laughs aimed at the 12 year olds that worked for this big kid too.Sure, there's little disagreement that the story sucks, the acting is barely passable, the plot confusingly complex and full of holes but you could say exactly the same thing for Star Wars if you hadn't been culturally saturated with the Star Wars mythos. And at least you won't have to put up with Jar Jar Binks...

reviews.review_title: Borderline nonsense
reviews.content: I'd heard once that the director of Dragon Wars made this film because he wanted to prove that Korea could produce a summer blockbuster on the same level as the Americans.I don't know if he actually said that, but it's definitely true about the film itself. About the time Dragon Wars hits its halfway point, it becomes an all-out special effects bonanza that tries desperately to emulate the level of insanity and destruction that directors like Michael Bay and Roland Emmerich were known for. And if that's all you're coming for, I suppose it's not the worst thing in the world.But it's everything surrounding the ridiculous "war" scene that's the problem. This movie doesn't have a plot so much as it has the suggestion of events, buffered by repeated bait-and-switch dream sequences. Can't understand what's going on? That's fine, it's probably just another dream. Still can't understand what's going on? Welcome to Dragon Wars.It's best to not question it and go with the flow, because the movie isn't going to make any effort to help you understand why any given thing is happening. Given that Dragon Wars is apparently based on an ancient Korean legend, perhaps it's just something lost in translation. But if that's the case, there's still no excuse for making it this incomprehensible. Characters come and go without any explanation as to who they were or why they were relevant, and random, inscrutable things seem to happen only to be hand waved away as being "just magic."It's hard to convey just how little regard the film has for its own level of coherency. I've somehow ended up seeing this movie three times now, and only by reading a plot synopsis on the internet (by people who are likely familiar with the original legend) did any of it begin to make any sense whatsoever.At the very least, you could consider this to be a poor adaptation of whatever Korean legend it is technically based upon. But you definitely can't pretend it's a good movie. Not in any way shape or form.

reviews.review_title: Cut and Paste Cinema
reviews.content: Everyone does things that they later regret. Things that they wish they could blame on drugs or alien possession. Things that although seem rational at the time, later reveal themselves to be engraved invitations for suffering and endless recriminations of stupidity.For some people it is signing the note for the new Hummer, for others it is picking up a homicidal hitchhiker, for still others it is sending their bank account information to third world millionaires mysteriously strapped for cash.For me it was a film.D-War: Dragon Wars In hindsight, I should have guessed how environmentally friendly and thoroughly recycled this movie would turn out to be from its stuttered and repeating title. But with my willing suspension of disbelief intact, and a naive faith stemming from the cool looking poster in the lobby, I really wanted this film to work. Sadly, by the time the old man in the pawnshop explained the entire backstory, fifteen minutes into the picture, I had the sudden, sinking revelation that comes from knowing every plot point of a still unseen film. And worse: I knew just how badly every point would all suck.Let me be perfectly clear here, the English language lacks sufficient nuance and depth in the field of ultimate evil to properly describe just how bad this film really is.As for knowing all the twists of movie, I was wrong. In the spirit of the old Godzilla films, whose scales this one is not worthy to fill, it conveniently sprouted extra sub-plots every time the main characters were threatened by the specter of meaningful dialogue.It was infested with close calls, miraculous escapes, and concentrated deposits of poorly explained angst.This film is what would happen if you gave the produces of the Mighty Morphing Power Rangers access to the national defense budget. And lots of liquor.Let me try to explain.Imagine you could get a hold of all the coolest-looking set pieces from successful action movies of the last decade: First take the rasta-talking army of amphibians from Star Wars Episode One and remove their Prozac until they are ready to club Navy Seals.Next, take close approximations of Kira Knightly and Tom Cruise (You can even call him Ethan as a "subtle" nod to the Mission Impossible franchise.) and give them lots of film noir narration, so no one get confused while trying to follow the wading-pool depths of their thoughts.Finally add a raspy-voiced villain in pointy armor worthy of a Lord of the Rings yardsale and a couple of giant cobras, angry at having their scenes deleted from latest edition of King Kong, and lay them all out in no particular order in modern day Los Angeles.Now run to the drugstore to find something for your sudden migraine. When you return, puree these ingredients until any overlooked hint of originality is dissolved into a homogenized mass of cheese and serve semi-gelatinous.At several points during this picture, I found myself saying out loud, "Make the bad movie stop," and breaking into tears.To call this a B-movie would be giving it an undeserved promotion. After summer school, and a lot of physical therapy, it might possibly pass for a C level film if you could somehow sleep through most of it.In short, if you ever find yourself with money and brain cells to burn, and the need to punish yourself for hideous, unspoken sins against humanity, Dragon Wars might just be the film for you.

reviews.review_title: I liked this movie even tho I didn't expect to.
reviews.content: I enjoyed this movie and I had very low expectation due to all the negative reviews I read before going. I went because I was curious as to what all this fuss was about because some of the postings were so angry with this movie and with the Koreans. Oh and it's from Korea which has put out some of my favorite movies. I liked Host but not my absolute favorite. Some of my favorite sci-fi /fantasy movies so you can have a sense of my taste: Mirrormask, Stardust, Serenity, Gattaca, Willow, Matrix, Resident Evil series, LOTR, Stargate, Dark City.It wasn't confusing like everyone said and the monsters looked good and the battles great. There are some holes in the story but didn't really matter. I sort of tune out stuff like that and stopped asking why long time ago when I see summer blockbusters. The Korean legend was interesting, the reincarnation stuff was different, and I thought the main characters suspiciously dressed like Korean actors in other shows. Ethan's(Behr)hair looked so Asian.Yes, it could be better and I hope in the future that Korea, with its unusual quirky sense of life, intense emotions, and unexpected humor, can bring some diversity to the blockbuster genre. Maybe a combination of Host and Dragon Wars in the future?

reviews.review_title: A lot better than I thought
reviews.content: I was unsure what to expect some friends loved it and others were very mixed. In fact D-War is Very Entertaining. It is far better than King Kong. The chemistry between Jason Behr and Amanda Brooks was riveting.She is a lot better (and prettier) than Naomi Watts. Jason showed that he is more than sugar candy. The CGI was top class. It's hard to find what the budget was. The consensus appears to be around $70 million. That's almost Hollywood blockbuster standard. I think this movie is going to have the same reception in America as in Korea. Bad from the critics but a big success with the public. The group that I went with ( there were 6 of us) all loved it.

reviews.review_title: Godzilla meets Starwars meets Kunfu meets Crappiest writer ever
reviews.content: Gosh... heu...mmm...ffff how to start, first I didn't understand the main story ...really , it is , I think, some kind of huge serpent dragon who wants to become more strong but has to find a girl with a mark who is born every 500 years , well it is kind of story that if you are not Chinese or Japanese (well here Korean) you cannot understand...well that's it , you know everything, ho yeah crappiest dialog ever , we are at the bottom of the sea , I'm pretty sure they will never take a quote of this movie for a movie trivia game.I give a 4, because it's a SF movie, for the special effects ,2 jokes with an zoo guardian, and a battle in a city between the US army and some medieval Galactica cylons mounted on dinosaurs shooting rockets. The story is dump and silly, the acting is poor, the dialog are crap, only the special effects save the movie for being a total infamy.

reviews.review_title: Better than Transformer, Great Ending
reviews.content: "Better than Transformer, Great Ending" is all I can say. I've been tired of Hollywood-formula SF movies, but this one, Dragon Wars, is different. Transformer has a fantastic CG, but other than that, I don't see any merit to enjoy it. Even the CG got me bored after half an hour. The ending was expected from the beginning. You know what? Most of the Hollywood SF's are like this, following the same formula... I'm sick of it. However, Dragon Wars is pretty new to me. The CG and action in LA are something different. I've never seen this kind of action. The way Burakee sweeps the roads made me feel thrilled. And the last part, ** Spoiler ** when the Yimooki turns into a Dragon and flies to the sky, it was very impressive. It's a totally different dragon we imagine. I like the ending very much. As William said, All's Well, That Ends Well!! Cons: Editing is not good at all.Overall, I would recommend this movie. What can I say, I enjoyed it!

reviews.review_title: Something I couldn't convince myself to like even as a kid
reviews.content: I remember seeing the first few trailers appear on tv and I was so excited my grandmother saw the light in my eyes and told herself that she had to take me to see this movie as she knew dragons are my favorite fantasy creature of all time. Now I am a huge fan of Kaiju and fantasy movies alike, I have seen every Godzilla film known to man and have rewatched them even as an adult. But when I tell you that 11 year old me was sitting in the auditorium, on the verge of asking my grandmother if we could leave and see a different film, that is precisely what happened. I will not talk about the low budget special affects as I've just praised the Godzilla films and we all know they can be pretty cheesy. But it was the fact that something I usually love and enjoy (giant creatures destroying things) bored me and I couldn't find an excuse to ever watch t again.

reviews.review_title: Either the Best or the Worst movie experience you will have all year!
reviews.content: Make no mistake--Dragon Wars is one insane, poorly written, totally psychotronic piece of drive-in crap. BUT if you're like me, and you used to go out of your way to see movies in the theatres like "Godzilla Versus the Smog Monster" "Golden Voyage of Sinbad" or "Humanoids From the Deep," "Dragon Wars" will be a magical trip down memory lane to the days when the term "Direct to Video" did not exist and every kind of unbelievable PG claptrap played your tiny local multiplex. This is hard core, kitsch-driven, bad dialog, nonsense-plotted kaiju movie fun that is distinguished from the most laughable of the Godzilla films only by its top notch, nonstop CG monster action, which is much, much more effectively utilized than that in Peter Jackson's horrible King Kong remake. So, if you're into seeing a really fun splashy, totally-mental, big screen B-movie goof fest that wouldn't seem out of place as a Mystery Science Theater 3000 entry, this is your flick! You won't see anything like this on the big screen again for a long, long time!

reviews.review_title: Surprisingly good considering...
reviews.content: ... the cover makes it look like a Godzilla movie.I bought this used for about 3 bucks, figuring it would be low rent, trashy and kind of fun.Instead, I found a movie with amazingly high production values and an interesting peek at a foreign culture. I think a lot of the reviewers here came to this movie as Americans expecting American sensibilities. While the location and actors are mostly American, the story telling and sensibilities are clearly Asian and all the creative forces behind this movie were Korean. (As anyone who actually read movie credits could find out.)It does take a few odd jumps of plot... how they feds find the cave the evil dragon (technically Imoogi) is lurking in half way through the movie seems unexplained, and you have to just understand that the end takes place in a spirit realm that is the home of said Imoogi. The former felt like something was left on the cutting room floor, but the latter I think is probably something that anyone from the culture of origin would have grasped immediately. And frankly I liked that it didn't stop to say "This way, stupid Americans, to the spirit world..."The production values are outstanding, at times mixing live action and CG better then I have ever seen before. (Though at other times I couldn't help but to say to myself "oh, nice composite shot.) The movie does drag on a bit during the human/Imoogi conflict. I personally would have cut some of this and put in something to cover the aforementioned cave, but all in all this was a VERY enjoyable film for anyone interested in fantasy literature about the myths of places other then the British isles..

reviews.review_title: Every 500 years...
reviews.content: ... a movie comes out that sucks this much.Holy crap this movie was bad. This movie needed to be either a lot better (like say, King Kong) or a lot worse (say, like Tremors). At least Saturday night SciFi Channel original pictures have funny, creative deaths. Granted, the dragon special effects weren't bad, but the dialogue makes George Lucas seem like William Shakespeare. Notably the other special effects are laughably bad (most notably anytime there is a car crash).The acting is atrocious. These guys make Keanu Reeves seem like Laurence Olivier.If you want a really bad dragon movie that's at least somewhat entertaining, check out Dean Cain in Dragon Fighter (2003).

reviews.review_title: D-Wars - great action sequences and SFX. CGI is top notch... but...
reviews.content: This is a failed attempt by a Korean director to make a western style film, they must have had a great budget and wasted it most of it on CGI instead of important elements of the film, like story and character development.The movie has your "typical trendy" Korean film feel. The characters are good looking, young and dressed as fashionable to be. As much as they are good looking, the characters are boring and unintelligent through out the movie. The story of the legend is laid out like a Princess Bride style story telling narration, then jumps right into scenes with high quality CGI, unfortunately that's its only strong point, the CGI.This movie looks like a well done, very clean, Hong Kong style movie. It doesn't even compare to most of the Korean films that have done well. This movie is to entertain kids for a couple hours but it seems it COULD have been interesting movie for adults 18 to 35, but it looks like they aimed the story to be for kids from the jumping around scenes, shallow character development and high number of very expensive CGI scenes which have a resemblance to scenes done by Lucas Art and the Star Wars movies.In comparison to other Dragon movies, it's not even close to being as good as the classic of Dragon Slayer and also sub-par film, The Last Dragon, which was a joke of a film but it was entertaining with a comedic element to it. Both these past Dragon films have characters whom one could relate and follow through out the film while D-Wars is a cold, CGI filled film with real live human action in it for some reason.

reviews.review_title: A Blockbuster B-movie of a Korean Legend set in the US-- is it a sign that the end is nigh?
reviews.content: {rant start} I didn't want to believe them at first, but I guess this is what people are talking about when they say South Korean cinema has peaked and may even be going downhill. After the surprisingly fun and moving monster movie "Gwoemul" (aka "The Host") of 2006-- which actually succeeded in making a sharp satire out of a B-movie genre-- successive Korean blockbusters have become more and more generic, even though their budgets (mainly spent on special effects) have become more and more fantastic. Do South Korean movie-makers really want to squander all the audience and investor goodwill, which their industry has built up since the 1999 break-out film "Shiri/Swiri", by making a whole series of big budget mediocre movies like mainland China did? {rant end}The only "reason" I can fathom for making this movie is to dupe the investors into financing the most detailed and fluid digital animation of a Korean/ East Asian-styled dragon I have seen to date, for the final scenes. Now if they had introduced that dragon at the beginning and given it more personality and purpose like in the 1996 "Dragonheart", the movie might have had a few more redeeming qualities other than having lots of digitally animated dragons. Remember "Dungeons & Dragons" in 2000? Hasn't anyone learnt that the trick is not how MUCH special effects you use, but how WELL you use it? I hope there are more (and better) Korean legends they can use, because they have just killed a lot of international interest in Korean dragon legends with the way they filmed this one.In short, I agree with all the negative reviews gone before and wonder how Koreans felt about having their folk anthem "Arirang" being played at the very end. As a creature feature, I would have given it at least 5 stars out of 10 if the special effects or action sequences had been worth it, but I've seen many video games with better camera work and scripting (just less dragons).

reviews.review_title: this had potential to be fairly decent film...
reviews.content: However if it was done in a way that would have been decent, then American audiences probably wouldn't have liked it...go figure...So what have we here? A movie that has American players who can't make it in American cinema, so the go to the east and become korean players who are supposed to act like they are korean actors acting like Americans...We have some rehashed cutting room floor footage of episode one (star wars that is).A bit of LOTR... The stuff that didn't even make it from storyboards to be cut...A token black guy......Lessee what else...Oh yeah... And strangely enough... mortal kombat...at least that is what it felt like in the end...and for the most part, the animation looked like something from a made for TV hallmark movie (think dinatopia, which is good for TV, just not modern cinema).As I said above, this movie had potential. It had a lot of potential, but what ruined it was the simple fact that it was americanized. Had the whole story taken place in ancient Korea, had NO American ACTORS WHAT SO EVER, then this movie would have actually been pretty good.My wife and I saw this with a group of people, and not counting the six of us (yes six gullible people paid money to see this...) there were only two other people in the theatre. Quite frankly, i spent most of my time laughing hysterically at the American stereotypes of the film. That and my friend who happened to be hopped up on energy drinks and espresso provided us with commentary.I should have seen the signs that this movie was no good. In fact I did. the reviews on IMDb and rotten tomatoes basically held this movie in the same breathe as Uwe Bowele (or however you spell that dudes name). If you have ever seen or heard of him, then you know what I am talking about......and you know a movie can't be all that great when you can't even find a camera rip of it online anywhere...I like foreign films, however I like foreign films to be from their own culture. Not trying to be like our own. It's as painful as watching Turkish Star Wars. There is something seriously lost in translation when this happens. Which, i might add was where the fundamental flaw in the dialogue occurred. The inflection, the meter, everything just sounds wrong.It's sad to see that this is the type of movie that the sheeple of America think is great foreign cinema. now because of it, good movies that are foreign stand less of a chance of actually making it over to the American mass market.but hey, as long as we have gallons of soda, economy size popcorn bags, and excessive amounts of cgi, why should we complain? ...baaaaaaaaa.....

reviews.review_title: The Koreans give us an Uwe Boll movie
reviews.content: Completely retarded Lord of the Rings rip-off, supposedly based on a Korean legend. The movie was made by Koreans, but it was aimed at American audiences. Please let this not be a trend. This is one of the most inept films I've ever sat through. Dull, terribly edited and directed, with an incomprehensible plot and just plain bad CGI monsters. There are times when this reaches the coveted so-bad-it's-good level, but it takes way too long to get to the titular war. When that starts happening, it's laughable and entertaining (for all the wrong reasons, of course). The two leads are utterly boring. Jason Behr in particular seems like the homeless man's Skeet Ulrich. And it's pretty sad that they kill off the cute minority girl (Aimee Garcia) and keep around the homely white chick (Amanda Brooks) to be the heroine. It's kind of sad in general that Korean filmmakers would have their legendary heroes reincarnated as faux-hot white people. I guess they were thinking they knew their audience. But then again, they don't. Why would anyone feel Americans would like to sit through a movie where their military gets decimated by a bunch of lizards? I think even war supporters are more than a little sick of seeing soldiers die, and more soldiers die in the approximately 20 minute-long D-War than have died in the Iraq War. There's one awful(ly humorous) scene where a pilot flies his helicopter into a skyscraper. We see the man jump out of the copter, as if he's going to escape, but, no, KABLOOEY! I feel sorry for all the nobodies who had to appear in this movie. Sure, they got a pay check, but who would really want to put this on their resumé? I particularly feel sorry for character actor and Oscar nominee Robert Forster. He clearly got paid the most for his appearance, seeing as he's the most recognizable face. I know character actors do whatever comes their way, but there is the occasional time when you should choose to retain your dignity.

reviews.review_title: I've seen a lot worse
reviews.content: I actually enjoyed this movie. The key is to set realistic expectations. Lets face it, two dragon/serpents on a DVD cover coiled around a skyscraper. Who's going to expect Casablanca? For what the movie tries to be it succeeds. The acting is standard, the character development is weak but who cares? The movie is about the special effects. Anyone watching this expecting more than what it was really didn't pay enough attention to the concept. If this had been done as an anime film nobody would be complaining, they normally aren't strong on character development either unless it's a 2+ year series. I can't even count the number of anime films that dropped me off in the middle of a plot with no explanation. You get used to it and take it for what it is. At least it didn't take itself seriously, that would have killed it.Light entertainment, decent effects, enough plot to carry the effects. That's all you need for this type of film.

reviews.review_title: Not the worst movie ever made at all!!
reviews.content: I felt the need to type a review on this film after all the negative comments about how bad this film really is ,cause its not that bad at all!. I think people have missed a very important point that this film is nothing more than a children's adventure with a mixture of cool effects (some of which are computer game based for kids who love computer games!). Further more the plot is of an old korean legend with dragons, wizards and helpers who kick arse!....Fantasy storytelling at its best....And no its not the best film ever but nether was godzilla which one critic gave 1 star, yet i loved it as did lots of my family, friends and other critics!. This film has everything from stars wars to lord of the rings incorporated into the story and effects....so what?...Thats why i enjoyed films like this as a child.It reminded me in parts like the 'never ending story' which as a child i truly enjoyed!.....So those adults out their that still have a little bit of child within them, go take your kids and enjoy this entertaining movie!!.

reviews.review_title: not worth a penny to see it, not even on TV. skip this movie!
reviews.content: I'm giving this movie a 1 because there are no negative numbers in IMDb rating system. this movie was horrible. It was very badly acted, the story was poorly written, the action was unbelievable. I doubt even the Salvation Army could battle as poorly as the troops did in this film. I won't even write any plot spoilers because the movie just isn't good enough for plot spoilers. To write comments on the plot would be pointless. If I were to compare this movie, I'd have to compare it to Reign of Fire, however although I didn't like Reign of Fire either, that movie at least was better than this one. Some of the people in the theater left before the movie was even halfway done. The only reason I didn't was because I simply didn't think to do it. I was hoping for a feast of CGI and fighting masterfully done, but that isn't what happened. The martial arts lasted all of 30 seconds and that was from an exercise routine done during the flash-back scene, very disappointing. The CGI was not done well either. One scene comes to mind. During one of the earlier tank battles, the troops are firing away at......nothing. Someone forgot to cue the animation guys on that bit of film so the street was totally devoid of bad guys. I'm also thinking the bad guy's voice was dubbed by the voice-over of Imotep from The Mummy movies. Had that same scraggly echoing thing going on. (Someone owed some royalties, here?) Since I mentioned the fight scene, I'll say yeah that might be considered a spoiler, but only to the purists I suppose.Don't go see it, don't buy the DVD when it comes out either. You have been warned.

reviews.review_title: Don't waste your time or money...
reviews.content: This was like the worst movie I've seen this year. And I have seen some baaad movies. It was like an episode of power rangers except that power rangers is supposed not to be serious.Acting was the worst, especially the lead Jason Behr, nothing he said or the way he did things could seemed like it was a part of the movie.The visual effects could have been worse, but they used far too much. The CG was not credible, and really calling a big snake a dragon does not work.The story, well it had potential, with some changes here and there, but no, for some reason they decided to keep it. I'm not sure if the movie was made for adults or children, but I don't think it works for either.I believe far to much money was wasted on this production, I think they would gotten better results they had burned the money and tried to heat a cup of tea with it.

reviews.review_title: funny how all the people from "south Korea" rated 10
reviews.content: this movie was HORRENDOUS. the story was cheesy and there was such a HUGE gap distinguishing the computer graphics and the live acting. The comments above that gave 10's CLEARLY are biased because the director was Korean. That can be the only explanation for a person from Harvard University Films Studies to applaud this movie to such an extent; No?I TOO am Korean and I watched the movie just yesterday but I refuse to be biased about it. I'll say it as it is, the movie was horrible.The TRAILER was actually more entertaining than the movie itself. D-war just didn't meet my expectations.

reviews.review_title: Crap, utter crap
reviews.content: This film was dire, like most was given the warning but stubbornly thought the film could be okay, i mean i am guilty of liking crap movies, i thought the new Highlander was okay, the 4th Crow wasn't that bad, but this, this is bad.Where do i begin. For starters the movie just isn't well made, every lesson that is taught in film school is flung out the window. Clichéd plot and cheese are expected but the film goes to a whole new level. For starters there are far to few shots and the shots that are used are crap. The soundtrack is almost non existent only showing up every now and again. The acting, now the acting is something new, I've seen bad acting but this has almost no acting. The worst example of this is a bit where a girl walks out of a club and is cornered by 4 thugs, a man in black walks into the picture, throws them all away one by one and just walks out, and when i say throw them i mean grudgingly moves his arm a couple of times. This isn't an isolated incident either.There is also lack of continuity or explanation from scene to scene. The computer effects are alright but still manage to look as if it isn't real, but then most computer effects do so that can't be faulted. The lead actors try to convey a sense of worry and panic all the time showing no chemistry to each other or change in mood the whole film.I guess what I'm trying to say is yes this film looks great but it isn't, its dire. I wouldn't let a review put me off watching this piece of crap so i doubt this review will but once you do, you will know what i mean. As stated I've liked crap movies before, I've even seen trates i liked in movies i didn't but this is unredeemable.

reviews.review_title: This is not about Korean movie.
reviews.content: Being a Korean, despite the terrible reviews the movie received both in Korea and USA, I was hoping for the success of the movie, when it came out in the cinemas across USA.However, after actually seeing the movie, I'm now so embarrassed. I tell you, guys. D-War does not represent the mainstream Korean movie. In fact, I'm not sure what it represents.The plot is TERRIBLE. I'm not sure whether the actors actually read the script before they accepted the roles.The story jumps everywhere and the scene did not seem to match with each other.It was so obvious that Director Shim (whom I used to like very very much as a comedian) copied the movies from Star Wars I, Lord of the Rings and Armagedon (I bet neither George Lucas nor Peter Jackson have seen the movie).The US Army was fighting the bad guys, and almost matched with the Orks in the streets of LA, and what happened to them? And when Ethan and Sarah get caught, they have been transported to the Land of Mordor? How? Why? Where is it?? How did the Mordor come about??? I don't know. I'm not even a movie critic! Director Shim should really get the professionals to help him to make a proper movie, if he wants to continue making movies in Hollywood.Evenyone, you should watch "The Host" and THAT represents the proper Korean movie.

reviews.review_title: Eh.
reviews.content: I'll be simple - the movie wasn't the best I've seen.I've been a die-hard dragon fan since childhood. The plot of the movie was somewhat interesting, the acting was terrible and dry, and the CGI (in my opinion) was good. Though, there was not any blood I can recall (not that gore is always a good thing. But when you get bit by a large serpent, you'll bleed), not to mention that the ending was absurdly cheesy. The ending was extremely dry. The main character, Ethan, didn't even shed a tear when the person he loves and the person who basically was like his father both 'died'. Then he walked off, and it ended. It made me snort, actually, that it was that stupid.There were only three things I recall; first, when the evil dude (I forgot his name) merged through the fence and the old woman tried it - I'm a sucker for stupid things like that and I cracked up. Second, was when the same evil dude got hit by the car. I bust up laughing and giggling. And third, was the CGI. I wasn't really expecting the serpent's (Imugi somethin-rather) to be just that - serpents. But it was interesting.With many flaws, dry acting and cheesy dialog, along with a semi-predictable plot line, D-War isn't one I'd recommend buying, or seeing.

reviews.review_title: D-War
reviews.content: I never heard of this movie and just watched it on ShowTime Arabia while on business in Kuwait and thought it was much better than I thought it would be. Several points of criticism would be: 1) the energy level for the two leads (Sarah & Ethan) was a little too low; 2) several plot holes (i.e. the dragon seems to mysteriously know where Sarah is at a given time and then can't seem to know where Sarah is at a given time); 3) the anemic response by the Dept of Defense of a significant attack on LA, when all they can do is send in a few Apache helicopters? Where were the fighters, etc; 4) the final dragon-on-dragon fight at the end goes on a little too long. On a positive note: 1) the special effects were excellent; 2) the military jargon was spot on; 3) I liked Craig Robinson (from NBC's The Office (USA)), Elizabeth Pena is always good in any roll and is really due for a major part in large Hollywood movie, and finally both Robert Forester and the FBI Agents & Sec of Defense were fine. Of special note is the energy and emotion brought to the screen by the Korean actors, all excellent and in many ways better than their American counter-parts. I think D-War could be somewhat better if it could be tightened up here and there to shorten some of the battle scenes (Korean fight 500 yrs ago, LA battle, dragon-on-dragon).

reviews.review_title: The rating is biased by (nationalist) Koreans - that movie is really bad and boring
reviews.content: Don't be motivated by the rating of that movie. It's biased by the (nationalist) Koreans who want to support 'their' director. Ridiculous. Koreans are well known for such childish behavior (When Korea dropped out of the soccer world cup 2006, Koreans attacked the FIFA server so heavily that FIFA had to block all IP addresses from Korea ...)To put is short, this movie is bad. And boring.This movie is not just a wannabe mix of Hollywood's StarWars, Lord of the Rings, Black Hawk Down and Jurassic Part. No, it's a very, very bad wannabe mix of all that. With all respect, Mr Shim, what have you been doing over the past 5 years of directing that movie ?I think he wanted to do the sort of epic sci-fi action movie. But for that you need much more than just a cluster of mega-flop computers. Instead of relying on actors, the director relied on computer power. Even worse, the director tries to impress the audience by showing some selected martial art sequences which are nothing but blunt copies of 'Crouchint tiger, hidden dragon'. Those sequences don't even fit into the overall making style of the movie.For sure we can not reward this director for finding new and innovative ways of action-movie making.What the sci-fi action thrillers Jurassic Parc and Co. have in common is at least a decent plot, thrilling moments and some good, authentic acting. But this movie doesn't have any of that.Moreover, the actors don't reveal any special characteristic of the person they act. It's so sterile. A kiss, what even in mediocre movies is a long suspected and awaited moment comes here as an unexpected sudden and sterile act (at the beach ... how romantic) The director should have used the computer for the main actors as well, it wouldn't have made any difference and he could have saved time and money.No thrills, no surprising moments, no dramatic, nothing.Don't waste your time on that movie. I recommend to rent a DVD of Jurassic Parc 1 instead. Even if you saw that one already 4 times.

reviews.review_title: Power Rangers - The Movie, or something like that
reviews.content: The only reason why I rented this movie was Jason Behr. I remember him from the Roswell days and wanted to see him in a movie as a leading actor.The movie has no real story whatsoever and actually nothing really happens. The heroes have to do nothing at all to achieve a happy ending and save the world.The entire budget was spent on the CGI, which was definitely below average. The creatures itself were pretty good, but they didn't really fit in the scenes and looked totally out of place.The acting was horrid at best. Amanda Whatever was one of the worst actresses I ever had to watch. She has no screen presence and not emotions. Jason Behr was also really bad. It looked like he was thinking ''Whatever happened to my career'' the entire movie. It looked like work and he did it to get paid.Somehow the director though that many action scenes equals a good movie. Well Dragon Wars is an Oscar winner then when using this measure. The ENTIRE movie is made of action sequences with no connection whatsoever. No storyline, no dialogue, no twists, no character development, NOTHING.All in a all it looked like a film made for TV. All the creatures and 'men in stupid looking costumes' looked like they came straight out of a Power Rangers film.

reviews.review_title: A must see - if you'd like to see, quiet possibly, the worst movie ever put into theaters
reviews.content: My boyfriend and I went to see this movie after the theater we went to had informed us that the original movie we went to see - Shoot 'Em Up - was down for the day due to problems with the projector.What a mistake! This movie is, by far, the worst movie I've ever seen. I saw Balls of Fury last week and even though it was SUPPOSED to be a stupid movie, it was NOT AS STUPID AS THIS ONE! There is no coherent plot, there is no coherent story line, there are no coherent actors (I'm pretty sure they had to be on something to be in this flick and think what they were doing was acting), and the CGI was almost worse than the old school use of claymation.The only good thing I can say about this movie is that it gave my boyfriend and I a lot to laugh about - first off at ourselves for being lame enough to see this movie, second after reading a lot of yahoo user reviews and reviews on here (one man said he'd shoot himself in the knee cap if anyone asked him to see this movie again) we felt highly entertained (though one could just read those reviews and avoid the movie and be fine), and third at how we could not name ONE MOVIE we've ever seen that was worse than this one.So if you LIKE terrible movies, like REALLY terrible, then this is for you. If you like things that won't give you a headache at how RETARDED they are, don't see this.

reviews.review_title: A mix of power ranger and godzilla?
reviews.content: I'm in Korea and all the media was going overboard with this movie, so I decided to go watch it.The director himself was a very popular comedian from the 80~90's, so when he came out with a movie pretty much everybody knew who the director was -- It's as if Jerry Springer came out with a movie, everybody would be interested and would probably go see it.The movie, in my opinion, to describe it in one sentence, was "A mix of power ranger with very expensive computer graphics." I heard the budget for the movie was 70 million USD which is a considerable sum. I read a news article today that World of Warcraft is being made into a movie with a budget of 90 mil (coming out in 2009).The computer graphics didn't mix well in places here and there, and I thought the storyline was terrible. There were some scenes that were out of place and doesn't really add up to the whole story. There's no build up. (especailly the medallion that goes off at the end) Overall, it wasn't worth the money or the time. Needs to seriously improve on the storyline.

reviews.review_title: D-War should be Z-War
reviews.content: D-War should be Z-War as in to catch some Z's which is the only way to make this horrid movie better.More importantly, I want to address the fact that 1,027 people logged into IMDb and gave this movie a 10 (I was generous with a 2). While I certainly have a healthy respect for other's opinions, this was clearly children rating movies. What use to make IMDb good was the fact you could trust the rating system (unlike Yahoo that is overwhelmed with 13 year old give a 10 out of 10 to any fart movie that comes out). Sadly, IMDb has strayed from is roots...Now back to the movie...In some 500 year repetitive cycle it seems that dragons can make their way to the starry heavens. Of course, there is always an evil one that wants all the glory and this will prove no exception. The story line includes a 20 minute back story and narration so we have some vague notion as to why we are watching this poor excuse of a movie. As a note, if it take you 20 minutes to explain the premise of a storyline then it is not worth telling.The acting is wooden (too bad for Jason Behr who once showed promise) and the special effects belong on a Sci-fi original movie. The good guys are bad actors and the bad guys are even worse. Strangely, the storyline seems to wander which is surprising since so much time was spent telling us why all this is happening. I would love to find something redeeming in the film and the only thing I can come up with is that the critics were spared a pre-screening since this movie was so bad that it should have not only skipped the theatre but the DVD release as well. It wasn't worth the ticket price (I did get a free pass from AMC Theaters after viewing it) and isn't even worth a rental or wasting 1 hr 40 minutes if it were free on TV.Here is some good advice, don't listen to 13 year old and don't go see this movie.

reviews.review_title: yikes...
reviews.content: OK this movie was bad. Really bad. How bad is really bad you may ask? Battlefield Earth bad. Ishtar bad. Bolero bad. Planet of the Apes (2001) bad. That is bad. reviews.review_title: Watch it
reviews.content: Considerable # of reviews criticize movie's storyline. In my opinion, story line was decent. I don't see any prob with it. During 20 years of watching Hollywood movies, I came across and had to cope with many, many stupid and ridiculous plots. I can't complain about this one. The scenes r visually profound and creative, and above all, very mythical & foreign. No American heroism, no same old Hollywood good vs evil/ hero vs villain fairytale--where there's always gotta be this one and only savior for all. What is unique about D-War is that its story and plot revolve around those mythical creatures and monsters rather than human hero& heroine. Monsters are beautifully rendered onto the screen and well-disposed to the taste and imagination of modern audience. Personally this movie was rather a renewing experience. Just.. sick and tired of Hollywood blockbusters involving thoughtless violence (that is somehow always gets justified at the end) and those salacious and sarcastic affairs, humors between the characters that r just getting worse and worse every time.Just Watch It!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! *...Strogly recommended....*

reviews.review_title: Awful movie

reviews.review_title: D-War: Dragon Wars... A movie as good as its title.
reviews.content: Okay, I don't want to start off on the wrong foot, so here is the verdict: You must go see D-War in theaters. Maybe more than once.This is one of the worst big-budget movies I have ever seen. Yes, it is worse than Van Helsing, though the creature CG looks a good bit better. This is worse than Armageddon. You won't believe it until you see it, but once you finally do see it, you will be so happy. The film starts off with a voice-over telling you a clumsily-worded legend. Then a hunky young reporter goes to investigate a scene of unexplained destruction in the middle of a city (obviously, we assume, caused by a dragon). He stands in front of a camera and talks about the incident, and he makes borderline metaphysical leaps of logic, such as, "The damage was so extensive that there are no eye-witnesses." ...? Then he sees a garbage can lid that is supposed to be a dragon scale. This causes him to suddenly remember when he was a child and Robert Forster told him a long story about how it was destiny to save the world. This story, at one point, takes the movie into four layers of flashback. I'm not kidding - a flashback within a flashback within a flashback within a flashback. This story also comes with a long list of vocabulary that you are expected to learn and remember for the rest of the movie. Nobody does. More generic plot unfolds. We are introduced to the movie's villain when there is a steady shot of a sidewalk and the side of a building, and he just walks into the frame, dressed like Darth Maul. Then he walks through a wall.Anyway, this movie sucks and is hilarious. People are arguing whether an Uwe Boll comparison is apt. Here's how I see it: no, it's not quite as bad as Uwe Boll. But it's close. The high-rent CGI and action sequences save this movie from the levels of degradation and shame that we have come to expect out of Dr. Boll. However, if you were to take away this movie's budget, I think you would basically have Alone in the Dark, except a little less confusing. At the same time, this movie has a different tone of badness. I enjoy all of the inherent hilarity in Uwe Boll's style of stupidity, but for some reason, I don't find myself feeling good about it. There is something reprehensible at the core of an Uwe Boll film, even though it may be funny to watch. D-War, on the other hand, has something positively cute at its core. D-War does make me feel good. This movie is adorably bad. It's like a kitten that you have to squirt with a spray-bottle because it keeps trying to get on the kitchen table.So, anyway, I couldn't honestly give it more than one star, because one star is what I think it deserves, but you should see it if you can. Get your friends together, get drunk, and go absorb.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as everyones been saying

There are millions of incredibly talented AND attractive actors begging for work out there - what happened? Watch her during a dramatic moment when Behr puts his life on the line for her - she looks vaguely concerned, as if Behr has developed a slight cough - maybe she should get some Vicks? WAKE UP!! This could have been a solid B movie, fun all the way through, but sadly it has true DVD status given this viewer's keen desire for the evil dragon to eat the leads.

reviews.review_title: PREVIEW screened !
reviews.content: Over the weekend, I had a chance to visit with Korean filmmaker /director, Mr.Shim Hyung Rae here in Korea, home to the Yonggu Arts and Entertainment Company. As we toured the rather spacious Digital Production studios located in a secluded area near Kimpo Airport , I got a sense of what really happens behind the scenes during the post production phased of a CGI film. D-WAR's the title of his latest movie and dragon war props appeared everywhere and were used in several sequences of the sci-fi thriller, five years in the making . Although I knew that Shim Hyung-Rae had a "reputation" that preceded him, I could not help but wonder if D-WAR was simply a remake of his previous movie aptly called REPTILIAN. After the first five minutes into the extended preview of D-WAR however, I knew that such conceptions I had of a boring remake was not only far fetched but a misnomer. The way computer science and technology are mastered here made it perfectly clear that the director has come a long , long way from REPTILIAN, a very low grossing film. Not only does Mr. SHim succeed in the use of a real plot this time but he casts real American actors not to mention a compelling drama that takes us back 500 years to a period of ancient history known as the Chosun Dynasty. But the director's "message" is just as relevant as it works it way through to present day Los Angeles. Even Mr. Shim himself is convinced that he's no longer a "mediocre" film maker as he plys his trade as a creative tour-de-force in directing CGI films.Will D-WAR defy any other description other than a "blockbuster" ? That question remains to be answered since the movie is set to be released this summer when we all get the chance to experience the absolute conquest of mankind . I did breathe a sigh of relief during a private screening and I was able to see some familiar faces on the big screen. The movie cast includes American actors such as dreamy Jason Behr and the hero Ethan Kendricks who must save Los Angeles from an army of ATROX soldiers.I figured most of the ATROX droids,clad in black armour were probably cheaper by the dozen to hire but as I found out later they were not hired extras but life size figures that were made from heavy metals and stored safely for future takes ! That was enough to convince me that there seemed to be a greater magnitude to this sci-fi flick than meets the eye.There's even a newborn baby that appears all too real but she too was made from an incredibly realistic computer rendered model. I took careful production notes about the advanced computer animation process that was used and I was also shown how the crying baby was preserved in glass and an exact replica of someone's first born.As we winded up the tour, the most pressing question in my mind was what becomes a legend most for Mr. Shim, a long time veteran in the film making business who has made over 20 films. The answer seemed to emanate from his most ambitious project: The I-M-O-O-G-I-'s of course! That's a Korean word for a mythical creature that evolved over time and it's in D WAR that the IMOOGI attempts to morph into a defiant dragon.In closing, I'd rate D WAR a solid B+ for its exciting visuals and explosive scenes that keeps a pace all its own. Also in production for Mr. Shim's next movies are GOSEONG LEGEND and a computer animation feature based on the life of myriad fishes in the sea.ANNONG !IRENE NAKANO /HARVARD U. FILM STUDIES( e-mail me: yonsei @ mac.com )
