reviews.content: I gave this movie 10 stars, just because so many people have given poor comments, on this all in all OK movie. its typical to hear from so many USA comments, that this movie is crap (in terms of story, plot and acting).... but if i would compare this movie with matrix revolution for example, than i would say, that THIS movie is a winner. my opinion is that its not fair to give this movie just one or two stars, its really not so bad at all. children likes this movie a lot, thats my experience and i like the stuff coming from Korea (like HOST, and i am not a korean :)).i liked IMDb a lot, for useful information on movies, but people who bad-comment movies like this one, makes this place more and more questionable. its sad to say that, but its the truth. there are too many movies over and underrated here, in the last two years. so i cant rely on a rating given to a movie, even if i know that this is tasty choice, given up from users who saw the movie.

reviews.review_title: Incredibly, Fantastically, Irresistibly Horrible Movie.
reviews.content: Let me say this once. This movie is a fine family children movie, cause of the intense CGI. But nothing more. This is a horrible movie, which supposedly was based on a GREAT legend. The characters, acting, directing was all plainly crappy! I would rather watch Disney Movies, because they actually have an excellent plot and rather fun to watch. This movie does not come close to the idea of ENTERTAINMENT, and it's a symbolic disgrace to the movie industries, and South Korea. Not only was the crappy lines more irritating, but also the music was. So if you're the fan of incredibly crappy movies that make it funny, be my guest and watch this. And in advance, i wouldn't even buy the DVD.

reviews.review_title: I wish I could say more than one thing good about this movie...
reviews.content: ...but I can't. To me, this movie has no redeeming qualities and I am surprised/shocked that it ever got past a test audience, assuming the producers ever showed it to a test audience.First off, the opening sequence had no back story--we never know why, in the scheme of the movie, the first events occur. This is followed by an what seems to be an eternity of long, drawn-out explanation in the form of flashbacks to different eras. I thought the movie was supposed to grab you in the first ten minutes. If this is true then this move failed that test entirely.The rest of the movie was incoherent at best and a mess at worst. A lot of the problems were due to the lack of continuity in the scenes. For example, one scene shows a number of military types running out a tunnel and firing into the air with no dragon in sight. Then, as if by magic, there are only ten soldiers left standing with bodies and wreckage surrounding them, yet no explanation of what happened. It was as if the whole battle scene was edited out leaving the audience to wonder what the heck happened. Unfortunately, this lack of continuity was pervasive throughout the production.The acting, on the other hand, was not bad considering the material the actors were given. I especially like Robert Forester's characterization of a mystic. His was the one bright spot in an otherwise bad movie.Overall, this movie could have used a reworked script, better direction, and much greater effort in maintaining continuity. As it is, in my humble opinion, this movie is pretty much unwatchable.

reviews.review_title: I begged the guy next to me to shut the DVD on that bus trip.
reviews.content: But no. Spending the 2 hours of my life watching something as off as this makes me realize how I would be the guy in the next row. Sleeping and oblivious to watching a movie that was just what wanted me to sleep.Let's just say the movie itself was a Korean folktale go West. But then, the guy didn't have inherited and magical/ kung-fu powers. The girl was hopelessly useless even if she can be more athletic than the rest of the people, and that she dream that bad things that happen. And Runs. The monsters have no true scientific weakness. And yeah, the bad guy speaks Korean. Do the guys even know what the hell he's saying? And the guy and the girl became boyfriend and girlfriend 2-3 hours after first meeting. Sweet.The plot was full of holes I can't understand. Okay, how does the person know that THAT bad guy was looking for the girl? How the man will go back home? how the hell do they take elevators due to an emergency... How did they go to the beach so fast! Why did the guy look for the girl? The Only thing good about the movie was the CG. That's it. Spending 75 million dollars on the CG that looks like a PS3 Video game but horrible acting, lost plot lines, and such nonsense of dialog that you would realize that you just want to go out that bus window and die on that highway... Well, that's exaggeration, but something to get into the feeling.Plus, this was a popular movie in Korea. Yeah. Not much to say there. The Koreans in the US Expected the Movie to have the Korean Flair. Where was it? So in the end. D-War will only work if you wanna abbreviate a pretty good Chinese game called "Dynasty Warriors", But then, the Korean film got that title first. Now to find a new abbreviation.Other words. Don't watch it if you still want to feel the 2 hours rushing sweetly in your face.

reviews.review_title: Horrible movie - Top candidate for the Golden Raspberry Award
reviews.content: Went to see D-War with a couple of friends. Just expecting hardcore action, not the deep-sense-and-romantic-thing.After, we felt ripped off. The trailers and other poster adverts (and the title) promise ways too much. The title is inappropriate : There is no war in that movie.Had to flush it down with a couple of beers afterward.Some people gave it a 10 star rating on IMDb !! Don't believe that !!It was so boring. And the plot's execution is so dilettantish. At times I had to laugh, not because it was funny but because I felt embarrassed. It was just too ridiculous: The FBI appears out of nowhere; a sudden, obligatory kiss; sequences bluntly copied from 'StarWars' and 'Hidden Dragon'; characters appearing without us knowing what they are for ... One of the most ridiculous things : The main actors are eternally chased in the city, they can never escape. But suddenly, somehow they managed to escape to Mexico. At that moment, I was about to leave the theater.Terrible. There are few basic rules with which you can easily turn a bad movie into a mediocre one. The director apparently doesn't know any of those. One of those rules is to let your actors act.The actors : Under that director it was just impossible for them to develop any decent acting. Even if this is a debut movie for some of them, they may just have ruined their career. I feel so sorry for them. That movie has the best conditions to become number 1 for the Golden Raspberry Award.

reviews.review_title: A Pierce Brosnan look-alike with an extra shot of estrogen.
reviews.content: This little movie gets unjustly trashed - considering that almost any vacuous left-wing garbage with Sean Penn or Michael Moore gets an average rating above 7, no matter how inept, nonsensical, or unintentionally funny it is, i.e. no matter how dragon-like it is. If half of the world can worship low-IQ, sexually frustrated film-making bipeds, then certainly we should be able to give a few confused Korean lizards a fighting chance.In all honesty, what exactly is the difference between Liberal propaganda thrillers such as "Syriana" and idiotic lizard flicks such as "Eragon" and "D-Wars"? Both sub-genres lie to us about the world; the former claims that man is inherently good hence deserves a merciless tyranny to help him pave the Golden Path to perfection i.e. Utopia (I know, the logic here escapes me, too), while the latter claims that mighty dragons exist but that they rarely catch their designated human prey in spite of their size and agility. So both sub-genres pray to the same god, don't they? The God of filmic BS.The poor slithery clown who chases our romantic couple never quite catches them. I don't know why that is. He certainly manages to maim half of downtown L.A., but whenever he finally gets anywhere close to killing the journalist geek and the tattooed maiden, whenever he catches up with their slow two-legged pace at last, what happens? The lizard inexplicably stops, takes a break, ends up just staring at the two in fascination(?), awe(?), fear(?), love even(?), confusion (because he doesn't understand his role in the script?)... pity even (because he knows that their acting careers are over, whereas even slow, ineffective lizards can always find parts in moronic fantasy flicks?).I don't quite understand how they did that... No, no, I don't mean the spiffing special effects applied to the lizard as he demolishes L.A.'s beauty salons and other important American businesses, but how they managed to make the geeky journalist look even more like an effeminate version of Pierce Brosnan. Did they apply even more woman's make-up on him than they did with Pierce in his James Bond turds? Even Di Caprio doesn't give us this much estrogen while impersonating men.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful roller coaster ride!
reviews.content: Saw this film many times with packed houses filled with families and teens. They LOVED the dragons and the action and the humor. While not for high brow critics looking for Academy Award fare, this is far better. A movie that pleases everyone and makes going to the movies fun again. Love watching Dragons attack Los Angeles. What could be better! See it on the first weekend! The story goes from ancient Korea and the legend of the good dragon and the bad dragon and the love of two people and transcends time to modern day Los Angeles, where the star crossed lovers are reincarnated and still under peril from both the good and the bad dragons. The dragons fight it out on the streets of L. A. in search of the girl who has the power to save to world. It's a roller coaster ride filled with some of the best special effects this year. And very funny too. A +

reviews.review_title: Here come the dragons...
reviews.content: Upon watching Dragon Wars, I was expecting to see a cheesy, foreign fantasy flick. I thought the special effects would be terrible and the acting would be bad. Turns out I was half right. Sure, the acting was wooden and annoyed me, but the special effects were honestly some of the best I've ever seen. Seriously.The actors give poor performances, as well as the entire supporting cast. The dialogue is also a joke. Even the voice acting is crummy and the soundtrack unremarkable, but the reason this film deserves a 7 out of 10 is truly the realistic effects and brilliant battle sequences.It's exactly like a Sci-Fi channel original movie with bad acting, silly writing, and dumb special effects... only in Dragon Wars, the special effects are phenomenal. If you're a fantasy nerd, and want to kill an hour and a half of your time, then crack open a couple beers and enjoy D-Wars. The acting is truly mediocre, but with the superb visuals and CGI, it's worth your time. Give it a chance.

reviews.review_title: Have I not seen this before?
reviews.content: I spent 90 minutes standing in HMV torn between 3 DVDs that I might buy. One of which was Dragon Wars. My friend convinced me into buying this DVD, and it was probably the worst judgement of trust that I've ever put in anyone. This is without a doubt, one of the most pretentious, self-obsessed, badly-made films that I have ever seen. In film's synopsis, it is proud to state that the film's budget came to $75 million, which (in the special features), director Hyung-rae Shim says is "not a lot". Considering that they used "not a lot" of money making this film, it is also approximately 38 times more than the average person in Great Britain will make in a lifetime. Now, see if you recognise this story: 'There is an ancient legend that is only reawakened every 500-or-so years to reak havok. There is a good side and a bad side - although usually the bad side seems to have exponentially more fighters, despite never winning the battle - boy is put in charge of protecting something; boy meets girl, boy and girl fall in love despite knowing each other for maybe a week. All ends happily ever after, whether everyone lives or not. Throw in a few scenes that don't link together, a few more that make no sense, and some incredulously naive characters, and you've got...' this crash-site of a movie. If you recognised that plot, then I know that we're thinking on the same wavelength. Within the first 15 minutes of the film's opening, we've seen the entire movie. Main character 'Ethan' has a flashback to when he was about 10 in an antique store run by the 500-year-old 'Jack' played by Robert Forster (who is actually the best actor in the film). We then see the entire story line play out to the backdrop of Korea, just shrunk down into the quarter-hour audience attention-span. From that point on, the remainder of the budget is spent on telling the whole thing again, just at 5 times the length and making it not quite as interesting. This film has one incredibly impressive feature, however. And that is the use of the stunning CGI-effects that have been loaded onto the project. Yet still, this is not a redeeming feature; the awfulness has already infected our systems too deeply to matter. I can see, somehow, just why Mr Shim saw it unnecessary to hire actors with any form of acting ability. And it's probably because the actors are only on screen for about 20% of the film's runtime. In fact, I'm pretty sure most of the mangled extras are on screen for longer periods. Furthermore, Hyung-rae Shim has not got an inkling of an idea about how to direct a feature film. His idea of keeping suspense up seems to be placing the camera in front of a 100-foot-high CGI snake and zooming in-and-out a few times between each cut whilst the seething monster rips apart vast office blocks in downtown LA. I myself am a film director. Making films is always a struggle, because, believe it or not, they cost money. Every day of film-making costs you more money. And in a feature film where someone finds it 'necessary for the story' to plonk a tank in the middle of a street in Los Angeles, you can expect that maybe the budget could be shoved up just slightly. In the special features, Mr Shim explains that he went to American composer Steve Jablonsky to create the soundtrack for the film. Mr Shim explained to him for a while about the soundtrack, and Mr Jablonsky wasn't very interested. Then, Hyung-rae showed him a graphic from the film, which changed Jablonsky's mind about doing the project. I'm just guessing here, that he probably didn't show him a first cut of the film; because I think Jablonsky's reaction to that may've been to turned around and jump head-first through his office window to the street below. At one point during the conversation, Steve Jablonsky made an inquiry about money for his work, and Mr Shim replied, "not much." A quote that he jokes about on the special features. Now, at this point, I lost all consideration for this man, and any aspect of the film that I may've enjoyed before then, went straight out the window. Seventy-five-million-dollars?! Seventy-five-million-dollars?! How, on Earth, is seventy-five-million-dollars, "not much"? He then goes on to say that he made this film in English, compromising the main origin of the legend itself, simply so that it would appeal to more audiences. So that the advertising company could make more money. So that it could be shown in more cinemas. So that, in whole, he would make more money. This man is someone, like many other Hollywood directors of the same calibre, that should be banned from the industry for the rest of eternity. He is someone that does not care at all about anything to do with the story of this film. He has thrown $75 million dollars at visual effects and nothing else; just so that it will be impressive when the kids see it. The more kids like it, the more parents you've got that are gonna be dragged along to watch it. For every kid, that's at least 2 tickets; and if that kid brings a friend, then maybe they'll bring their parent too. You can see how, maybe, this movie's gross income could quickly build up; to pay this monstrous industry creation. Making this sort of film should be illegal. Or at least, there should be a MASSIVE sign attached to the front of the poster, DVD and every piece of merchandise connected to it, saying "This film is awful! Do not watch it!"... if this happens; then I'll be satisfied.

reviews.review_title: If I Could Go lower then 1 I Would! Avoid at All Cost!
reviews.content: Plot: Basically this story is revolved around 2 characters that are decedents of 2 past heroes. That are destined to return or reincarnated at a new future time. Then they will fulfill a prophecy of 2 creatures locked in a past battle (Dragons AKA Snakes). But the new reincarnated couple find each other (How Convenient) and try save the world from annihilation, from the evil dragon and his super force.My Spiel: First of all I went to go see this movie in the theaters. Let me be the first to say this had to be one of the worst abominations to ever hit the big screen, and my eyes at the same time. First of all I watching the previews and then 20 minutes goes by, and then it dawns on me this movie started 15 minutes ago. All I could say was "Rescue Me" this is horror that I didn't even know it started. There were no titles at the beginning. But this movie was so full of flaws, not to mention the cheesy acting. Who ever thought this movie was good has absolutely no taste. Another note I was dragged to going and seeing this movie. This was not a movie I wanted to go see in the first place. But sure enough I thought about 20 times leaving this crap bomb. But let me say this movie is called Dragon Wars, and The 2 main creatures weren't even dragons but giant snakes. The only time you saw a dragon was at the very end when one apparently earned it's wings for some unknown reason, But at this point I was just wanting to get the hell out of the movie. Two scenes in particular were when the army was attacking the super evil army from years in the past, and they were shooting at absolutely nothing. Another scene was how conveniently the 2 main characters find out that they are part of a destiny to stop this unstoppable force and magically find each other in this mess. This movie was made for the effects only, and that is all it had going for it. But with a Craptastic story, acting, and characters you just don't care about. Its pointless. And that 1 out of 10 review isn't a typo. Its for real. Avoid this crap fest at all cost.Dragon Wars (D-Wars) (2007) Review: 1/10

reviews.review_title: Great Good Imoogi! Was this mediocre!
reviews.content: I was stuck for something to do. And, the early-bird matinée of "The Brave One" was sold out. So, I went to see this, instead.A mixed blessing, at best. Having grown up on the giant rubber monsters of Toho Studios, and the stop-motion epics of Ray Harryhausen, I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed the Battle of the CGIant Snakes, at the end.I also enjoyed the subtitled prologue as narrated by Robert Forster's character (who, I'm guessing was supposed to be an Amerasian reincarnation of Haram's original sifu). Plus, the nods to classic monster movies of the past, like "beast From 20,000 Fathoms" and the 1933 "King Kong." Plus, my recognition of "Roswell" alumnus Jason Behr as Ethan. And, last, but not least?The fact that this was one video game-adaptation NOT directed by Uwe Boll! The rest of the movie, though? Well, let's it put this way. The fact that Behr and Forster were the ONLY big-name actors in the principal cast will NOT guarantee big returns for this flick at the box office. I was one of three people watching this movie when the opening credits started. And, I WAS ONLY THE ONE _STILL_ WATCHING IT WHEN THE ENDING CREDITS STARTED!Hence, only five stars. If that stills make it sound satisfactory to you? Vaya con Dios, amigo!

reviews.content: Well it's not really worth 10 actually(even quite far from it) but I have seen far worse movies during which I was bored from A to Z and even a few (2 actually) that I could not watch till the end who had been given better rating than D-Wars, so I wanted to try to bring back the balance toward a 5 which seems correct to me.Give it a chance if you want to enjoy a bit of cool CGI, a great city fight sequence (as good if not better than Godzilla's) and some cheesy bad acting rather funny when you know what to expect.Keep in mind this movie is not a Hollywood multi-million Blockbuster, this is a Korean Movie, made in Korea, yes it's made for the international screen but it doesn't play in the same level of competition, therefore I would say that it's pretty damn good when compared to what s**ts Hollywood produce for far more money.Get it from a rental shop when it's the rent 2 get a 3rd free movie so you don't feel robbed and can assume full responsibility, take your drinks, order a couple pizza and enjoy it.You will see that they are still very much into imitating the Big American brother (Godzilla chopper Vs Dragonets, Chronicles of Riddick's armour type"ish", Phantom Menace animal/weapon mounts, Two Towers for the architecture at the end...)...Hope it helps

reviews.review_title: Resurrect dragons revive a Korean legend.
reviews.content: Convoluted, confusing and hard as hell to follow. Albeit, some real good special effects. This movie is about resurrect dragons from a Korean legend smashing and bashing around California. Two creatures of legend, a Good Imoogi and a Dark Imoogi, both want to become heavenly dragons. Director Hyung-rae Shim has these giant creatures morphing from serpents to dragons and back again with massive armies of very formidable monstrosities. A young woman turning twenty years old, bearing a red dragon tattoo on her shoulder is the key to consummating a legend spawned a half-millennium ago. I can't believe I wasted my time watching this mess and still have no idea what I watched. At least it was cool watching the dragons and their minions battle. Starring are: Jason Behr, Amanda Brooks, Robert Forster, Craig Robinson and Aimee Garcia.

reviews.review_title: Dragon Wars
reviews.content: Okay, there are two dragon serpents. There's a bad dragon named Buraki, the other a good dragon named Imoogi. Both desire to attain a human sacrifice, and neither was able to do so 500 years before this film's contemporary setting. Sarah(Amanda Brooks)is the reincarnated spirit of the Korean girl who committed suicide with her lover before Buraki could get to her. Ethan(Jason Behr)is a LA newspaper journalist and the reincarnated spirit of the one assigned to protect Sarah in the previous life, and is called on by Jack(Robert Forster, a guardian protector in his own right whose role is to make sure Ethan and Sarah succeed in her sacrifice to the good Imoogi so that the world will not be overcome by evil and terror)to see that this time the great event can take place and that order can be restored without Buraki itself attaining her. Atrox(Jesse Jam Miranda)is the one responsible for Buraki receiving the sacrifice so that evil can rule the world. Got all that? All this just to see a dragon snake and a monstrous dinosaur army led by foot soldiers obeying the command of Atrox to destroy everything it their path to get Sarah. If you want to see a metropolis under attack by CGI creatures with lots of buildings exploding and collapsing, with fighter planes and heavily equipped helicopters attempting to stop them, this is your movie. From what I understand this was financed by South Korea and I can see why so little inspiration was given to actual performances of worth. This complex story-line I grew tiresome of, but maybe kids will enjoy the live action video game that Dragon Wars is. One sequence where the Buraki serpent slithers up a skyscraper known as the Liberty Building to catch Ethan and Sarah is an obvious homage to King Kong. The sequences where flying fire-breathing pterodactyl type creatures, walking dinosaurs which are equipped with launchers that fire off missiles, soldiers in suits of armor(..carrying shields)as they target structures and human life with our armed forces using tanks and other firepower at our disposal might remind you of Star Wars(..preferably The Return of the Jedi), and there's a deadly fight to the finish between the Buraki and good Imoogi which closes out the movie. Behr and Brooks spend most of their time on the lam as the Buraki constantly closes in, leaving wreckage after each location. There is this talisman around Ethan's neck and Sarah has the scar of the red dragon both of which play major factors at the end of the movie when it appears that Atrox and Buraki have finally gained the upper hand. I guess many will consider the dragon serpent fight at the end a colossal clash of the titans, reminiscent of the Godzilla monster battles of the past in Japan. The reliance on CGI is overwhelming. Forster's character morphs into various people to assist Ethan and Sarah.

Whatever, I'm going back to my trailer to pick my nose, if anyone calls for me, I'm not here." Shame on you whatever your name is. Shame on you.

reviews.review_title: Outstanding movie

reviews.review_title: not too shabby,in my opinion(but what do i know?)
reviews.content: maybe i need to have my head examined,but i thought this was a pretty good movie.the CG is not too bad.i have seen worse.the look of the creatures(and by creatures i mean the good and the bad snake)was pretty cool.the action scenes involving the snakes was really good,i thought.there are some lapses in logic at times,and the story doesn't always make sense.but for a creature feature,there are a lot worse.a lot of the other creatures seemed lifted from other movies,so it's not wholly original.i think the gist of the story is original though.there is a bit of similarity to Godzilla(the Big budget American version)which liked a lot.i didn't like this movie as much,but i still say it was pretty good.i also liked the music.all in all,i think Dragon Wars is about a 7/10

reviews.review_title: Hilariously bad but entertaining
reviews.content: To start off, you cannot take this movie seriously, its another movie based off an old Asian legend. The plot makes very little sense if any, very difficult to follow, the acting was pretty mediocre at best. But to be honest, the movie was entertaining, it was almost non stop action the entire movie, which is what kept me from turning the movie off. reviews.review_title: A Korean Movie...with Jason Behr.
reviews.content: Call me crazy, but shouldn't a Korean movie, oh I don't know...star Korean actors?!?!?!?! I had the pleasure of an advanced viewing of the Dragon Wars DVD. Most of the time, I spent the viewing thinking, "Wow, this is a hybrid of Lord of the Rings, Star Wars, and Godzilla". The acting was awful by Jason Behr, and the rest of the cast that shall remain nameless...and mainly forgettable. However, one thing cannot be denied in this film, and that was the special effects. The dragons, the weird creatures that were never fully explained, were all very well done, and had that same muted naturalistic look like the autobots and decepticons in Transformers. Come to think of it, it was done very much in the styles of Michael Bay, and the score was actually done by Hans Zimmer's troupe that actually worked on Transformers. I watched the special features and learned that Director Hyung-rae Shim was making his first attempt at breaking the international scene. He mentioned that rather than using a design company for his special effects, he created his own. This, I have great respect for. He said, in so many words, something that I agree wholeheartedly with: There are two "T"'s in movies, Talent, and Technology. Perhaps he needed to work a bit on Talent part of those "T"'s.

reviews.review_title: Worst Movie Ever

reviews.review_title: It doesn't matter where you're from, this movie bombs
reviews.content: Prior to the premiere of this film in Korea, every time I watched the news, there was some story about D-War.... mainly about the Korean director, who was a comedian awhile back, and how it cost $150 million and 6 years to make. But the biggest factor for this film's hype was that it was a Korean film being filmed in LA with American actors. This film was all based on hype and national pride and as a result it totally did not deliver. I don't care if you're Korean, American, European, or anything else, but if you can honestly look someone in the eye and say that this film was excellent, then you have got to be a great liar. To give this film some credit, it HAD the opportunity to become something great. It was actually a good plot, but it tanked on so many levels, from the failed CGI, to the poor script, to the poor acting, and to the insanely evident cheese factor. Oh, and just because the actor's were no namers, it doesn't mean that it was bad. It was bad acting because they were just bad actors, plain and simple. The script was way too cheesy and the bad acting just made things worse. Also, despite the fact that it cost $150 million to make, it seems the majority of it was used to get the license to film in LA. Yes, I KNOW that this movie is about dragons and I shouldn't be too scrutinizing on the CGI, but Jurassic Park was based on dinosaurs and that was made over 10 years ago and managed to have better graphics than this. The CGI didn't converge well with the rest of the scenery and made a terrible clash.I think I was soooo lucky to have watched Transformers AFTER D-War because if I saw it the other way around, I would have walked out of D-War. D-War may have set the record for best opening in Korea, but to be perfectly honest, it was all based on national pride, which isn't a bad thing mind you. But once this film hits America, it's going to bomb. It won't have the same popularity as Shiri, Old Boy, and Lady Vengeance which didn't have a big opening in Korea, yet found fame in the global film industry.

reviews.review_title: Very bad plot, not bad CG. But there's something you don't know...
reviews.content: OK.This movie failed in many aspect. The biggest problem is that the plot has big holes everywhere.But, I think most non-Korean failed in understanding why so many Koreans moved by this ugly-plot-movie.In my opinion, the patriotism is not the answer. Koreans are not naive that much any more.I think the reason is it's the first movie that visualize the legend of Imoogi and Korean-style dragon.I heard that many Korean who watched the movie said the plot was terrible, but in the last battle scene of "Imoogi and dragon", they felt something.I think the director failed in telling the story itself, and so failed in giving some strong impression.Koreans were generous to this movie enough to ignore the big holes in plot, so they felt some impression that might have arisen either in non-Korean's heart, if the plot was good enough.

reviews.review_title: Main reasons for its popularity in South Korea
reviews.content: 1. PatriotismPeople in S. Korea believe that D-War is going to do well in Hollywood and show the world that a Korean movie can be as successful as any other blockbusters made in U.S. They don't see D-War as a movie, they see it as a representative of their country. Hence the frantic support, just like they did for their soccer team in FIFA World Cup 2002.2. NationalitySomewhat similar to patriotism, D-War includes their national theme song 'Arirang' at the ending credits. Also during the intro of the movie one of the actors mention the words "This is a Korean legend.." which again amplifies the fact that it IS a KOREAN movie. Korean people just love that, as they are all eager to advertise the Korean movie to the world.3. Home-made CGUntil now, almost all of the CGs in the blockbusters made in Korea has been imported from overseas. However the CGs in D-War was actually done by a small Korean company. This was a major breakthrough for the Koreans and this adds more value to the movie in Korean people's perspective as they are able to boast about their CG skills to the rest of the world through D-War.4. Sympathy for the DirectorThe director of D-War 'Hyung-rae Shim' was actually a very famous and popular slapstick comedian. During the peak of his career as a comedian, he suddenly decided that he wants to create movies and went on to create quite a few low-budget movies. They were all criticized and failed horribly in the market due to their lack of quality. Shim lost most of his fortune he made as a comedian during this process and people began to sympathize for him. When Shim announced that he is making a huge blockbuster costing near $75 million U.S dollars, the public was very supportive of him and the movie as a whole.The combination of all 4 factors mentioned above have turned D-War into a major success in Korea. However the critics have criticized the movie for its lack of plot and using the mentioned factors to lure people to see the movie. Of course non-Koreans don't care about any of these factors, they only see the movie as it is. This is why the movie won't succeed in the countries other than Korea.

reviews.review_title: Recommend this for a bad movie night.
reviews.content: This movie was only good if you liked movies that had almost no plot, poor sequencing and an overall sense that something was missing. Like good acting.There were a few funny points in the movie and the CGI was fairly good, but that is where the praise ends. This movie fell flat because of a few basic problems. First of all the back and forth of the time line to set up the story was poorly done, you easily got lost and confused. The rest of the city seemed to be unaware that it had been attacked by gigantic reptile creatures and were living their lives in blissful ignorance. Then there was the strange scene changes...where the hell did that city come from? I know that you are supposed to suspend disbelief, but damn it was hard in this movie.I give this move a D rating, only because it was actually funny in places.

reviews.review_title: Not That Good, But Not Bad Either
reviews.content: Before I started writing this comment, I went through the comments and reading it made me chuckled ! Many reviewers gave poor rating for this movie, and many made comparisons with other sh*tty movies, some of the movies which doesn't survive in the movie, whilst some was copied directly to VHS. C'mon, this movie has got to be at least better than those crappy movies, right? To be fair, the CGI is not bad at all! Whilst not as good as Transformers or Lord of the Ring, this movie's CGI is not as bad as 'Monster'. The dragon is made with details, its movement is very nice. The fighting scene between the good dragon Imoogi & the evil dragon Buraki is very nicely done, too. And the scene where the evil soldiers marches towards the altar also made it worth the watch.While some may disagree with me, I think that the storyline is built-up in a good way. The narration by the old man, the 'visions' experienced by both the lead actor & actresses, and even the flashbacks of the scene where their village is destroyed by the evil forces and Sarah Daniels' father killed was wonderfully made.In my opinion, the poor rating of this movie is because of its predictability. Hey, maybe it does not take a genius to know that good will prevail over evil, but it does not make this movie bad. It is like watching sports movie where the hero/heroine will most definitely win.All in all, it is a good movie to relax after a hard day at work. The storyline is good without being complicated and the soundtrack is nice to hear. If you are looking to watch complicated storyline with equally complicated twists and turns, then maybe you should stop watching movies all together. Watch TV series i.e Prison Break & Heroes instead.

reviews.review_title: Decent production values wasted on a terrible story
reviews.content: Dragon Wars did have potential to work and ought to have done. But what we had was a film that did have that potential but wasted it with poor execution. I will give it some credit and say that the scenery and settings are beautiful and the effects while not great are at least decent, an asset I was dubious about in all honesty. The dragons do look imposing and do have presence which does elevate things a lot. But oh my goodness so many things spoilt Dragon Wars. The direction is nothing but flat, everything just lacks life and nothing stands out. The dialogue is very poor, with cheesy one-liners and hackneyed flow of the overall script, while no time at all is spent developing the characters, all they are at the end of the day are standard and in some cases annoying clichés. I have no better news about the acting either, Jason Behr is hopelessly wooden and has no charisma whatsoever. Robert Forster was the best of the entire cast, and even he was generic. But what really made Dragon Wars as bad as it was was the story. It is one thing to have a simple story, but when it is over-simplistic and structurally thin that is another matter entirely. Everything lumbered on with no sense of heart, surprises or excitement while any climatic scenes felt rushed. Overall, the production values and dragons are not bad, but everything else pretty much is. 3/10 Bethany Cox

reviews.review_title: D-War is a movie about an ancient Korean legend.
reviews.content: This movie was pretty bad...when I first saw this movie on advertisement, and since I am Korean, i was thinking, "Wow...finally a Korean movie being released to major theaters in the USA!" I went to see this movie and it was disappointing. the actors were absolutely terrible!! for example, when Ethan is tied to the pole and Sarah is captured, he just yells "Sarah!" without any facial expressions. and it felt like he was just saying it. also, all the actors had terrible unrealistic reactions to the dragons. i mean if u saw a dragon, u would be like omfg run!! but no. and the lines ere SO cheesy. "Ethan, know that i will love you for all eternity..." yeah it was pretty bad.
